contentSection.headline: Master Discrimination Law That Protects Your Organization
contentSection.description: Discrimination Prevention and Defense is 2 intensive days where you'll master Title VII, ADA, FMLA, ADEA, and Equal Pay compliance—plus learn how to resolve claims without litigation and defend when it happens—working through realistic scenarios with experienced employment attorneys.
benefits: Complete discrimination framework – Title VII harassment, retaliation, LGBTQ+ protections, and compliant DEI programs
Accommodation and leave expertise – ADA essential functions, PWFA/PUMP intersections, mental health accommodations, and FMLA coordination
Defense strategies – Internal resolution, arbitration programs, EEOC process, and summary-judgment positioning
Professional certification – Earn your certificate plus 13 SHRM/HRCI/CLE continuing education credits

header.title: What You'll Master in 2 Days
header.description: A comprehensive discrimination law framework covering Title VII, ADA, FMLA, ADEA, claim resolution, litigation defense, and federal contractor compliance.

blocks.label: Full Program
blocks.title: Discrimination Prevention and Defense
blocks.description: Master discrimination law fundamentals and defense strategies across all protected classes.

competencyGroups.title: Title VII: Discrimination, Harassment & Retaliation (Still #1)
competencyGroups.description: Trends, hybrid risks, LGBTQ+ protections, religion, and compliant DEI.

skills.title: Charge trends
skills.description: Higher filings; retaliation remains most prevalent—action items for intake, interim measures, and documentation.

skills.title: Harassment in hybrid workplaces
skills.description: Chats/DMs, meeting recordings, and third-party/customer harassment—practical controls.

skills.title: LGBTQ+ and sex-based claims post-Bostock; religious conflicts after Groff
skills.description: Document undue hardship for schedules/duties while ensuring equal treatment.

skills.title: Reverse-discrimination / DEI backlash
skills.description: Run compliant DEI—widen access, use merit-based selection, and lawful outreach—amid scrutiny.

competencyGroups.title: ADA, PWFA, FMLA: Accommodation & Leave in a Hybrid World
competencyGroups.description: Define essential functions, align performance, and coordinate overlapping laws.

skills.title: Defining essential functions with remote options
skills.description: Use defensible analyses and documented rationales.

skills.title: Mental-health accommodations and performance alignment
skills.description: Balance supports with expectations and safety.

skills.title: PWFA / PUMP intersections
skills.description: Scheduling and break implications; coordination with other laws.

skills.title: FMLA interference/retaliation traps
skills.description: Coordinate ADA/FMLA/Workers' Comp to avoid compounding liability.

competencyGroups.title: ADEA & Equal Pay
competencyGroups.description: RIF documentation and privileged, action-oriented pay audits.

skills.title: Disparate impact and RIF selection
skills.description: Build selection files that hold up and avoid age bias.

skills.title: Pay transparency and equal pay audits

competencyGroups.title: Resolving Claims Without Litigation
competencyGroups.description: Internal resolution, arbitration programs, and mediation tactics.

skills.title: Internal resolution
skills.description: Prompt, impartial investigations; what to share in outcome letters.

skills.title: Arbitration & class/collective waivers
skills.description: Enforceability trends; drafting updates for remote workers and electronic consent.

skills.title: Pre-charge settlements and mediation
skills.description: Best practices to resolve early with durable agreements.

competencyGroups.title: Litigation Playbook (When It Happens)
competencyGroups.description: Administrative responses, ESI preservation, and summary-judgment positioning.

skills.title: EEOC process
skills.description: Position statements that help—and those that haunt.

skills.title: Preserving ESI
skills.description: Chat, personal devices, and cloud docs—issue holds that actually cover the risks.

skills.title: Summary-judgment and retaliation defenses
skills.description: Build the record early and avoid avoidable admissions.

competencyGroups.title: Federal Contractors & Affirmative Action (Hot-Button)
competencyGroups.description: EO/OFCCP landscape and DEI posture post-SFFA.

skills.title: Executive Order / OFCCP shifts
skills.description: What contractors should—and shouldn't—do while rules are in flux.

skills.title: Post-SFFA compliance posture
skills.description: What survives for corporate DEI vs Title VII; where to re-tool.

faculty.name: Ray Deeny, Esq.
faculty.title: Partner at Taft Stettinius & Hollister LLP
faculty.bio: Ray is widely regarded as a dean of labor and employment law, known for his encyclopedic knowledge and unmatched command of workplace regulations. For over 40 years, he has represented management nationwide, blending a powerhouse advisory practice with a formidable litigation record.

faculty.name: John F. Wymer, III, Esq.
faculty.title: Partner, Labor & Employment at Thompson Hine LLP
faculty.bio: John F. Wymer is a nationally recognized labor and employment attorney and partner in Thompson Hine LLP's Labor & Employment group. With decades of experience, he represents public and private sector employers nationwide in employment discrimination, wage-and-hour, labor negotiations, union matters, ERISA claims, and more.

faculty.name: Dawn R. Kubik, Esq.
faculty.title: Of Counsel, Kubik Workplace & Investigative Services
faculty.bio: Dawn Kubik is an employment attorney and founder of Kubik Workplace and Investigative Services and Dawn R. Kubik, P.C. With a legal career spanning since 1997, she has represented both plaintiffs and defendants in employment, personal injury, contract, and insurance disputes.

faculty.name: Rudi S. Turner, Esq.
faculty.title: Senior Corporate Counsel, White Cap
faculty.bio: Rudi is Senior In-House Counsel at White Cap, where she counsels and defends the organization as it responds to administrative agency complaints, potential litigation, and employee lawsuits. Drawing on extensive experience in labor and employment law, she supports leaders and HR professionals in navigating complex workplace issues.

faculty.name: Jacqueline E. Kalk, Esq.
faculty.title: Shareholder at Littler Mendelson P.C.
faculty.bio: Jacqueline E. Kalk represents and advises management across industries including manufacturing, construction, crowd-sourcing, and virtual companies. She focuses on independent contractor classification, wage-and-hour compliance, equal pay, and employment litigation.

faq.question: What happens after I register?
faq.answer: Within minutes, you'll receive an invoice email. Once payment is processed, you can schedule your complimentary pre-program consultation (10-15 minutes) to discuss discrimination challenges you're currently facing and identify which scenarios will have the biggest impact for you. Pre-program materials arrive one week before your session starts.

faq.question: What's the difference between in-person and virtual formats?
faq.answer: Both formats feature the same practicing attorney instructors, current discrimination law content, and professional credits. In-person provides face-to-face networking with other HR professionals. Virtual delivers the same live instruction via Zoom with full Q&A capability. Choose the format that fits your schedule—the quality and content remain identical.

faq.question: What continuing education credits will I earn?
faq.answer: The 2-day program provides 13 SHRM/HRCI/CLE credits. Plus, your enrollment includes 12 months of quarterly employment law updates (4 sessions × 1.5 credits each = 6 additional credits), bringing your total to 19 credits.

faq.question: Is this the same as Block II of the Certificate in Employee Relations Law?
faq.answer: Yes. Discrimination Prevention and Defense is Block II of the full Certificate in Employee Relations Law program. You can take it as a standalone 2-day program, or combine it with Comprehensive Labor Relations (Block I) and Special Issues in Employment Law (Block III) to earn the full certificate.

faq.question: We're seeing more accommodation requests. Will this help?
faq.answer: Absolutely. The program covers ADA essential function analysis, mental health accommodations, PWFA/PUMP intersections, and how to coordinate ADA/FMLA/Workers' Comp without compounding liability. You'll leave with frameworks for handling the most complex accommodation scenarios.

faq.question: How current is the discrimination content?
faq.answer: Very. The curriculum addresses post-Bostock LGBTQ+ claims, religious accommodation after Groff, reverse-discrimination and DEI backlash, hybrid workplace harassment, and the current OFCCP/affirmative action landscape. Our instructors update content based on cases they're currently handling.

faq.question: Does the $1,375 program fee include everything?
faq.answer: Yes. Your enrollment includes all live instruction from practicing employment attorneys, complete program materials, 13 continuing education credits, pre-program consultation, 12 months of quarterly employment law updates (4 sessions, $1,588 value), permanent access to updated resources, and alumni benefits for all future programs. The only additional cost would be travel and lodging if you choose in-person format.

faq.question: Can I apply this toward the full Certificate in Employee Relations Law?
faq.answer: Yes. Discrimination Prevention and Defense (Block II) counts toward the full certificate. You can complete the remaining blocks—Comprehensive Labor Relations (Block I) and Special Issues in Employment Law (Block III)—at any future session to earn the complete Certificate in Employee Relations Law.
